description:
We're teaming up with a few of our friends again this summer for a casual ride on the border to border trail (or as we like to call it - the brewery to brewery trail!)

Sunday, June 12
10am - depart Arbor Brewing Company Microbrewery in Ypsilanti. 720 Norris Street, Ypsilanti

The ride will take most people somewhere between 45 and 75 minutes

11ish - grab a bite to eat at Arbor Brewing Company Brewpub in Ann Arbor. 114 E. Washington Street, Ann Arbor

After brunch we'll ride back to the Microbrewery and relax in the beer garden with a pint of our B2B Trail Ale.

There is no charge or purchase required to participate but we do ask that all participants pre-register and sign a waiver. 

Proceeds from the B2B Trail Ale benefit the Friends of the Border to Border Trail: A group of individuals working to see that the Border To Border Trail is completed, maintained, enhanced and most of all, used. 

Ride notes:

-        The ride is moderate as the total distance is 20 miles with some hills

-        Solo Riders must be 12 years of age and trailers are aok

-        What to bring: water, spare tire tube, helmet

-        What not to bring: headphones

-        Remember it is the law to obey all traffic rules

-        Don’t forget to check your bike before the ride: breaks, gears, tires
name: Arbor Brewing Company B2B Ride

description:
On Sunday, June 12, UMMA will open from 10 a.m.–12 p.m. exclusively for a FREE ASD friendly program allowing families to enjoy art in a fun and welcoming atmosphere. Families will have access to special hands-on activities in the galleries that will help encourage exploration and discovery. Children will be able to make a Picasso puzzle, a Chinese rubbing, a contemporary sculpture and more, a few will be take-aways. Sketching and or writing materials will be available for children who prefer that to hands-on.

The Museum will also offer sunglasses, noise reducing earmuffs, and a quiet area with tactile toys for families who need to step away from the activities for a bit.

This event is recommended for ages 5-18, however all are welcome to participate.

REGISTRATION REQUIRED! 
Visit myturn.eventbrite.com to register today!
name: My Turn: A Sensory Friendly Sunday at U-M Museum of Art

description: We're breaking out our grill again to make you this delicicious Mexican Street Corn, served with herbs and spices, spicy peppers, lime, sour cream, and feta cheese- sooo good. Just 2/$3.
name: Grilled Mexican Street Corn

description:
UMMA docents will guide visitors through the galleries on tours as diverse as their interests and areas of expertise. Each docent plans a theme and includes a variety of styles and media to illuminate his or her ideas. Themes may be repeated but each docent's approach and choice of objects is unique.
Engaging with Art tours are generously supported by the Berkowitz Family Endowed Fund.
name: Guided Tour: Engaging with Art

description:
Arthur W. Wiggins is the author of The Joy of Physics (with cartoons by Sidney Harris) and the coauthor, with Charles M. Wynn Sr., of the The Five Biggest Ideas in Science, Quantum Leaps in the Wrong Direction, The Five Biggest Unsolved Problems in Science, and the textbook Natural Science: Bridging the Gaps. Wynn and Wiggins have also edited And God said, "Let There Be Evolution!”: Reconciling the Book of Genesis, the Qur'an and the Theory of Evolution. Wiggins is Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Physics, Oakland Community College in Michigan.

This lively and humorous book focuses attention on the fact that "science is a human enterprise." The reader learns about the foibles and quirks as well as the admirable ingenuity and impressive accomplishments of famous scientists who made some of the greatest discoveries of the past and present. Examples abound: James Watson and Francis Crick formed a legendary partnership that led to the discovery of DNA, but they essentially ignored the contribution of female colleague Rosalind Franklin. Later, in the race to sequence the human genome, Watson criticized J. Craig Venter's technique as a process that could be run by monkeys. Nikola Tesla once worked for Thomas Edison, but then quit after a dispute about a bonus. Robert Hooke accused Isaac Newton of stealing his ideas about optics. Plato declared that the works of Democritus should be burned. With tongue-in-cheek illustrations by renowned science cartoonist Sidney Harris, this book takes the reader behind the scenes of scientific research to shine new light on the all-too-human people who do science.
name: Meet Distinguished Professor Emeritus of Physics & Author Arthur Wiggins for a Discussion & Signing of 'The Human Side of Science'

description: Thursdays through Sundays June 9-26.  Check out Tickets Available link for arb member advance ticket info plus note Summer 2016 construction impacting arboretum area parking & traffic.  Arrive early for tickets and time to walk to location of the first scene.
name: Shakespeare in the Arb 2016 - Love's Labour's Lost Opening Week

description:
Ann Arbor Civic is hosting the Tony Awards!

Well, we're hosting a Tony-watching party, actually.
And YOU are invited!
 
Join us at 7 PM on Sunday, June 12, at the A2CT Studio (322 W Ann Street) for a red-carpet event.  PLEASE RSVP BY FRIDAY, JUNE 3!
 
We'll have a red carpet arrival, drinks and light refreshments, ballots for you to pick the winners, and prizes for those who chose the most actual winners. We'll also have the Tony Awards playing on the big screen while we mix, mingle, and celebrate our love of theatre!
The party starts at 7:00, and the Tonys start at 8:00
Come dressed for the red carpet, or as your favorite Broadway character!
name: Tony Awards Party!

description:
Enjoy hilarious video shorts created by some of our very own improvisers and also by professional, amateur and even wannabe film makers in and around the community!!

Here’s how it works: Each month we’ll get a new suggestion from the audience to use as inspiration for the next month’s “Pointless 730 Hour Video Challenge." Next, get to work creating your prerecorded masterpiece. Submissions can be no longer than two minutes in length.

And the coolest part - We will be taking your video and using it as the suggestion for an improv scene!!! IT'S A FREAKING VIDEO NIGHT/IMPROV JAM!!! People will LITERALLY be DISSECTING your video in the name of improvised comedy. What will they do with it??? Show up to find out.

Send your finished product to pointlessvideoshorts@gmail.com no later than the Saturday before the video night. And finally, come and watch the crowd go wild over your creative and hysterical work of digital media art.

Not into making vids but love watching them? Submit your favorite one from YouTube related to that month’s “suggestion” and we might play it on that Sunday! That’s right, you can share with the world that video you accidentally stumbled upon late one night while browsing the interwebs that made you cry with laughter.

Of course, you are not required to participate in any way. Simply come, enjoy a microbrew, sit back and laugh with some fellow funny people. Admission is pay-what-you-can.

Let’s get ROLLIN’!.
name: Pointless 730 Hour Video Challenge - June's Theme "Road Trip"

description:
Restaurant Week is your opportunity to try as many great Ann Arbor restaurants as your schedule allows for one incredibly low fixed price. $28 for a three course dinner! 

The Main Street Area Association (Main Street Area Ann Arbor) is proud to bring you Ann Arbor's favorite semi-annual dining event - Restaurant Week!
The specials run June 12-17th. Visit www.annarborrestaurantweek.com for details.
name: Ann Arbor Restaurant Week
